title: 9 Hot California Places for a Summer Escape
text:
Some places in California are great any time, but theses are especially nice to visit during Summer: June. July and August. Summer Flowers at the Coast Botanical Garden. ©2007 Betsy Malloy Photography. Used by Permission. 
Wildflower season comes later in Mendocino than other parts of California. The early summer blossoms make an already scenic coastline even more attractive. More » Lavender Garden at Ceago Vineyard. Jen/Flickr/CC BY-NC-ND 2.0 • Lake County 
A trip to the lake is always a good summer activity, and you'll find Lake County refreshingly uncrowded. 
It's just north of Napa County, with a nice lake, a budding wine region and some fun, little towns to poke around in. More » Inside the Los Angeles Theatre. Floyd B. Bariscale/Flickr/CC BY-NC 2.0 • Downtown Los Angeles' Last Remaining Seats 
If you love the films and grand movie palaces of yesteryear, this summer event is well worth the trip. 
In June, the L.A. Conservancy's annual series of classic films screens in the historic theatres of downtown Los Angeles. For some of them, it's the only way you'll get to see their lavish interiors. Mount Lassen. Lassen NPS/Flickr/15302047372_8d7d885850_o.jpg 
Before Mount St. Helens, Lassen blew its volcanic top in the early 20th century. Remnants from the eruption remain and the landscape is intriguingly volcant. 
This northern California volcanic park is best visited in summer, before it gets covered in snow. More » Street Mural in Pismo Beach. ©2007 Betsy Malloy Photography. Used by Permission. 
Summer and "beach" in California go hand in hand and the Golden State has plenty of them to visit, from urban to uninhabited. 
For a taste of iconic California summer beach atmosphere, you can't beat Pismo Beach. More » Things to Do on the Russian River. ©2010 Betsy Malloy Photography. Used by Permission. • Russian River 
Between the Pacific Coast and Sonoma, the Russian River area is popular with lots of people 
Hiking and horseback riding in Armstrong Woods, water play along the river, bicycling on the back roads make it a fun summer getaway. More » Afternoon at the Sequoia High Sierra Camp. ©2008 Betsy Malloy Photography. Used by Permission. • Sequoia High Sierra Camp 
If you like the idea of sleeping in a tent, but would rather have a comfy bed and a hot shower than a sleeping bag and wash basin, this is the place for you. It's only a short hike in from the nearest road and you can get the outdoor experience without sacrificing those creature comforts. 
This luxury, high country camp is only open in the summer. More » Giant Redwood Trees in Sequoia National Park. ©2009 Betsy Malloy Photography. Used by Permission. • Sequoia National Park 
John Muir called Sequoia a rival of Yosemite, but it's much less crowded than its sister park to the north. 
You can visit any time, but only in summer can you drive all the way down into Kings Canyon, which is by some measures the deepest canyon in North America. More » Leonid Meteor Shower Fireball. Courtesy of Getty Images News/NASA 
The Perseid meteor showers occur in mid August, with as many as 60 meteors per hour streaking through the sky. Death Valley , Big Sur , Mendocino and locations along Scenic Highway 395 are some of the best places to see it. Check the exact dates for this year . More » Related Articles
